f1Histories.description: The FIA Formula One World Championship is a high-speed, premier auto racing series. It began in 1950 with the inaugural season, featuring seven races.
Mercedes dominated in the 1954 season, with Juan Manuel Fangio winning his second consecutive title.
Graham Hill secured his first World Championship title in 1962, becoming the only driver to win the 'Triple Crown' of motorsport.
Niki Lauda's remarkable recovery from a near-fatal crash in 1976 and his rivalry with James Hunt became one of the most iconic moments in F1 history.
McLaren's MP4/4 car, driven by Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, won 15 out of 16 races in the 1988 season, showcasing their dominance.
The tragic death of Ayrton Senna at the San Marino Grand Prix in 1994 shocked the world and led to significant safety improvements in F1.
Mika Hakkinen secured his first World Championship title with McLaren in 1997, marking the beginning of his successful F1 career.
Sebastian Vettel became the youngest Formula 1 World Champion in 2010 while driving for Red Bull Racing, securing the title at the age of 23.
In 2020, Lewis Hamilton equaled Michael Schumacher's record with his seventh World Championship title, cementing his status as one of the greatest F1 drivers in history.
